name: (1E)-1-benzylidene-2-(3-nitrophenyl)hydrazine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-838
Reason: The target compound, (1E)-1-benzylidene-2-(3-nitrophenyl)hydrazine, contains several functional groups and structural elements that influence its melting point. The basic unit we can consider is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The compound has two phenyl rings, a hydrazone (NN=C) linkage, and a nitro group. Each phenyl ring will add to the melting point due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi interactions. The hydrazone linkage will contribute to the melting point because of its ability to form hydrogen bonds and its rigid planar structure, which favors crystalline packing. The nitro group is electron-withdrawing, which increases intermolecular forces such as dipole interactions and also contributes to a higher melting point. Estimations for each functional group effect: each phenyl ring: +30 due to increased molecular weight and pi interactions, hydrazone group: +50 due to hydrogen bonding capacity and rigidity, and nitro group: +40 owing to its strong electron-withdrawing character that increases intermolecular forces. When combining these effects, remember that not all effects are additive and may have a nonlinear impact when combined.
